												The game's main character, Violette Summer, is baased on the real life secret agent/saboteur Violette Szabo.  You experience her missions in Europe through her dreams.  In those dreams you become the actor and rely on stealth, wits, and weapons to take out enemies and complete mission objectives.  You'll start with a knife and have to be very careful to get to the first objective.  It gets harder and more interesting as you acquire more talents and weapons.  It is very challenging to  maintain stealth and operate with very limited weapons and ammo, which makes it very satisfying when you get to a mission objective.  Gameplay was engaging, exciting, and sometimes spooky.  The music certainly sets the tone for you secretative missions and dangerious scenarios.  The atmosphere is close to art and can evoke a lot of emotion!  While I thought it was a pretty good game, I have very mixed feelings about recommending it.  So this is a conditional  recommendation subject to some serious "ifs".  The game is old and relies on the outdated checkpoint system instead of real saves and the controls are sometimes clunky.  It probably won't run without some work on your part.  Unless you are willing to download additional drivers, tinker with file names, and maybe edit configuration files in an emergency; this game probably isn't for you.  If on the other hand you are willing to fix a few things on your own, if you have the mettle and patience to stalk and kill quietly, and if you can live with some gameplay bugs; then the game is pretty riveting and exciting. It could be a lot better by today's standards, but was pretty good when it was released.  I enjoyed playing for a short time, but decided to move on because of problems with the controls lagging and getting me killed when I played with an Xbox 360 controller with Steam Overlay running.    .....a.  It works flawlessly with the Xbox 360 controller if you can live without the Steam Overlay.  .....b.  If you want to do screen  shots with the F12 key, then the changes you have to make to get Steam Overlay to work may cause laggy performance with the controller, which makes it harder to play the game successfully......c.  If you play with keyboard and mouse, the controls are flawless with or without the Steam Overlay - definitetly best played with a keyboard/mouse combo.FIXING GAME PROBLEMS1.  Game Fails to Launch Issue....a.  Install the NVidia Legacy PhysX Drivers at http://www.nvidia.com/object/physx-9.12.1031-legacy-driver.html2.  Steam Overlay Fix needed if you want to do screenshots with F12....a.  Navigate to your Steam\SteamApps\common\velvet assassin folder....b.  Rename Launcher.exe to Launcher2.exe....c.  Rename Replay.exe to Launcher.exeCaution Note:  May cause laggy performance or other game issues3.  Checkpoint Progress LoopIt is possible to get to a point where you are encountering overwhelming odds and the most recent checkpoint just returns you to the same situation where you inevitable are killed and returned again and again like the movie Groundhog Day.  In such a case it maybe necessary to edit the values in the follow files at Steam\SteamApps\common\velvet assassin\aio....a. difficulty.cfg (NPCDamage and PlayerDamage - decrease the former/increase the latter)....b. weapons.cfg (Adjust damage  depending on situation)PROS*  Very chilling look into a very dark time in history through the eyes of a behind the lines assassin*  Good story style*  Edge of your seat encounters *  Offers around 40 hours of lay time - far more than a lot of other similar assassin type gamesCONS*  Predictable enemies and unrealistic situations with enemies facing away from threat vectors*  Stealth is inconsistent - in some areas you appear to be hidden, but can be discovered where in another location the same factors would render you invisible to the enemy*  AI is weak *  Sometimes gameplay is forced to a linear path and slow*  Sometimes controller mode controls are non-responsive resulting in you getting killed; e.g. you must be in a precise position to execute a knife kill or you just stand there getting shot*  Velvet Assassin was released in 2009.  Later that year the developer studio, Replay,  closed its doors due to insolvency.  As a result there is no developer support for this game.

												The Good:- Great lighting and environment design add immersion and remain consistent throughout- Unique protagonist and narrative offer a refreshing perspective of the WWII setting- Sound design is good; both music and voice-acting are executed well and add immersionThe Bad:- Very "trial and error"-based; requires A LOT of patience- The story is unimpressive and many levels feel fragmented or unrelated to each other- Controls feel clunky and restricting (in both moving around and in combat)In Velvet Assassin, the player takes on the role of British agent Violette Summers, infiltrating enemy lines to combat Nazi forces during WWII. Velvet Assassin offers an interesting and unique, albeit frustrating, stealth experience. While the game does some things well, it does many things poorly.To begin with, Velvet Assassin's story is not very impressive. I found this to be the most disappointing part of the game, especially considering the high potential set in place by the game's unique protagonist and premise. Taking place during WWII, Velvet Assassin sets itself apart from other WWII games through the way in which the story is told. After suffering a near-fatal gunshot wound during an assignment, agent Violette Summers remains bed-ridden in a state of comatose, recalling her missions through dream sequences. At the beginning of each level, Summers provides a little briefing on her mission, helping along the story via narration. However, while helping to take down Nazi forces is satisfying in its own right, the goals of each level are pretty much unrelated; one level will revolve around sabotaging a German ammo depot, while the next level involves assassinating a key target. While these objectives seem like fairly standard spy operations, Velvet Assassin does a poor job of tying the levels into an overarching story, making the goals of each of the levels feel insignificant.The game's story also finishes off in a sort of strange and unsatisfying dead end, which led me to question whether the developers had a different ending planned originally that was scrapped.While Velvet Assassin certainly has its flaws, it does do some things well.First of all, the sound of the game is great; the voice acting of both the protagonist as well as the frequenlty overheard conversations of patrolling enemies are believable and interesting. The music also does a great job of adding to the immersion and intensity of sneaking around in the shadows.The environment and scenery of the game is also another high point. It is clear that a great level of detail was placed into crafting each of the levels, and the striking silhouettes created by the game's bold colors and deep shadows are dramatic and impressive.The stealth in the game is suspenseful and carries with it a rewarding feeling when exectuted properly. The lighting really comes into play here; as long as Violette remains in the shadows, she is almost invisible to enemies, allowing her to close in for the kill. Velvet Assassin's lighting and ambience in each of the levels is excellent, helping to create interesting and believable environments. The game also provides ample opportunity for the player to manipulate the environment to create more shadows (e.g. disabling a fuse box to shut off the lights) so as to remain hidden.Some reviewers criticize the AI in this game for being "blind," but in reality, I think the portrayal of stealth in Velvet Assassin is actually among the most realistic I've seen in a game.However, the realistic and intense stealth does not necessarily translate well into fun gameplay. Ironically, Velvet Assassin's heavy emphasis on stealth is also what cripples the game in many other departments. First, the overall combat in the game is quite lackluster; aiming weapons, particularly in firefights, feels clunky and unnatural. While the game is obviously focused on stealth, there are several instances when sneaking around enemies is not an option and the player is forced into awkward combat situations. Additionally, because crawling around and methodically eliminating enemies one-by-one is so time-consuming and tense, it makes it all the more frustrating when you are caught while trying to take out the last enemy and are forced to repeat the painstaking process all over again.However, in spite of all of its flaws, Velvet Assassin is not a terrible game. It's a game that, unfortunately, could have been realized far better, but is certainly enjoyable at times, thanks to beautiful visual design, unique narrative and suspenseful stealth.

												i can partly see why this game gets mixed views. i avoided the game as well due the negative views i have heard and seen on youtube and other sites. but after seeing it for 0.74 cents, it was hard to say no and thought i give it a try regardless. i ended up liking the game. so here is my honest review.  now, as some may know, violette summers is based on a real life british spy named violette szabo. here a link to read about her:http://nigelperrin.com/violetteszabo.htm#.VbWBwfk1rKEit did make me wonder why they have changed the last name but i guess due her history that she was caught in her second mission and executed, would have been problematic from a historical point of view and maybe also due possible lawsuit issues. now to the game it self. lets start with the pros and cons of the game.cons:- the AI has its dumb moments. (will mention it a bit later)- repetitive remarks from the enemies.  - the shooting can be at times frustrating. especially the last mission. (will go in to detail later as well)- at times enemies know where you are, even when hiding in the dark. - HUBs dont really allow you to go around enemies. forceful confrontation is required. - the protagonists character is not explained at all. - no frontal attacks possible unless in morphine mode. - the menu cant be operated with a mouse. - must wait for for the counter to show the new number after reloading. pros:- very good voice acting. - great atmosphere.- beautiful lightening.- graphics are beautiful as well. - the german enemies speak actual german (which should be expected since the company is from germany).- the enemies have at times interesting and funny conversations.- the english subtitles are very well translated. report it, nothing. also, most of the time they know exactly where you are when alarmed, even when hiding in the dark without making a peep or doing anything that would get their attention. and im not talking about enemies who clearly saw me making a mistake, even those who come later to the party where everyone is dead and they still see you in the dark. their weapons already aim in your direction even when a wall, crate is in their field of view. but shoot of course once there is no obstacle in their way.   in one mission when being inside the gestapo building, the enemies spotted me when i was looking through a keyhole to see if the area is clear for me to walk out. for some reason, the soldier who walks past the door was suddenly alarmed and pointed his gun at the door. also oddly he and the others, who were a floor below, never bothered to enter the room i was in. or the the once below bothering to come up. also when being on the catwalk, the enemy below was alarmed since i walked exactly above him. nothing really happened since i was above him and generally invincible since i was wearing a SS uniform. thats a mechanic that could have been looked in too.which leads me to the change of costumes. its a plus of course but it has its downside as well that you cant be too close to the enemies. you have a depleting bar when you get too close to an enemy. if you are too close, you get recognized as a spy. i sure would have no complaints if a good looking woman (and she sure looks good in a uniform) comes close to me. like to know how every enemy would know every single female SS officer. would make maybe sense with officers but not some random soldier. you have no chance of being stealthy either.the shooting mechanic has its moments as well. especially the last mission you are forced to shoot instead of being stealthy. her accuracy is not always good. but these of the enemies are very precise and can hit you from a distance with a 98% success rate. also it gave me the impression that an enemy can handle a few shots and the other can handle half a magazine. so the ending led to some very frustrating outbursts. the reloading can be very frustrating as well. you must wait for the counter to display that it is full. if you start changing weapons or put the weapon away, it will not count as a reload. even when she clearly has finished it visually, you must wait a second for it to be displayed. so much for the picky parts. now to the parts why i ended up liking the game, even after mentioning a lot of the bad things of the game. the stealth was very solid and you get immersed quickly. stabbing the enemy did not get old. she kills them in different ways like putting a bullet through their heads, stabbing them between the legs, slicing their throats, and stabbing them repeatably which are all visually very violent. the game requires you to be careful and i just had to laugh when reading from others that the "checkpoints are too far away". i never thought they are too far away. they were placed very well. if you rush it, of course you will have issues. you have to be careful and observe the enemies what they are doing and then take them out one by one. avoid using the firearm since you will need it by the end of every mission to shoot your way out. the missions are diverse. so not only "kill this guy and kill that guy". you have to find an fallen agent (and the ending of this mission is not what you expect) or plant a bomb. also the germans speak actual german and was amusing at times listening to them. since i know german, after growing up in the german speaking part of switzerland, the repetitive remarks they have are these:Hoffentlich kommt bald die Ablösung. - hopefull the replacement comes soon.'nen Schanpps wär jetzt gut. - a schnapps would be good now. So viel Spannung is es ja kaum auszuhalten. - so much tension is excruciating. Hier passiert ja so wie so nichts. - nothing really happens here. Und wer macht jetzt den Dreck wieder weg? - and who is cleaning up this mess?Hab sie erwischt. - i got her. Sieht nicht gar nicht mal so schlecht aus. Das Luder. - doesnt even look that bad. the minx. thats pretty much it. the locations are visually impressive to look at. some of them can be a bit dull but you are in a ghetto, sewers, prison complex, church, catacombs, a huge garden or a village. also you see some graphic scenes as well like dead civilians lie around, hanging from trees, being burned. and children are among them too. so this alone creates a very intense atmosphere. plus the very well made dynamic lighting add more to these scenes. even when violette at times looks like a plastic doll, so as some enemies, but since you will see her mainly from the back (which is a nice looking back) and the HUBs as such looks really impressive, i think i can close an eye on that little feature. the gameplay is solid and works really well with M&K. it displays the M&K buttons, you can customize the layout to your liking but as mentioned before; for some reason you cant operate the menu with a mouse. so over all, if you like a solid stealth game, have patience and can see away from the bad feature i have mentioned, you might find some enjoyment from this game which i think has been underrated.

It wants to be a stealth action game drenched in gritty realism, but the level of bad game design decisions and massive number of bugs keep me from recommending this game to anybody.* Don't expect to be able to avoid or sneak past encounters. Sometimes you'll kill an enemy and it will be completely silent. Sometimes it will alert the enemies the next room over.* The shooting mechanics are bad, supposedly to discourage mindless combat. But then the game forces mindless combat on you, most of the time without warning you.* The environments look good, but they'll repeat themselves so many times it legitimately feels like you're just playing the same level again and again.* Checkpoints happen once every 20-30 minutes. In gameplay sections with lots of enemies where most of your time is spent waiting doing nothing, this can get very frustrating very fast.Whatever this game's strengths, they're far overshadowed by really poor design and technical mishaps that really takes me out of the experience. Can't recommend it.

												I bought Velvet Assassin on discount, it was very cheap and looked interesting. In the beginning it had all the right boxes ticked and I thought surely this is one of those underrated games. After several hours playing I can confidently say it isn't.It's difficult to pinpoint exactly what is wrong with it, it has good presentation and production value as well as pretty good voice acting. In reality I can't really say something is "wrong" with it, just that the designer(s) made a heap of really weird decisions that led to an incoherent downright boring game. Here's a list of things that I consider to be bad design decisions that hurt the game a lot: You're an assassin and obviously level designers have gone through the difficulty of setting up things so you can get in take out your targets and get out without being spotted. Except when the game suddenly expects you to blow up soldiers, electrocute them, set them to fire in order to get the next "rusty key" as a drop from dead enemies which will open the door out to the next area. That kinda kills the whole purpose of being an assassin.  At times instead of giving you something that a female assassin could use to escape, you get a shotgun. Really? a shotgun.. you couldn't have picked something quieter. I played past half the game and not once did I get a silenced submachine gun, sniper or a cross bow or something like that which all existed during the timeline of the game and more assassin-y. First few chapters I noticed the number of weapons and items was very limited, I thought it's going to get better and surely some new mechanics will be introduced as I progress through the game? No. I just kept replaying the same mechanics with the same weapons, no feeling of progression at all for several chapters. The only time something new happened is when I got to wear an officer disguise to sneak into a heavily guarded place by just walking. This disguise only lasted a segment of a chapter and that was the only time I got the option to do it so far. Character level progression could simply be based on experience gained through gameplay, but that makes sense and the designer(s) of Velvet Assassin don't seem to favor that. There are "collectibles" you have to pick up to get experience and some enemies drop collectibles when killed, which is yet another contradiction to the whole assassin thing. I played past half the game and I still didn't get any real story. You got a sort of description of your mission at the beginning of each chapter but that's not a story. Then you get some weird morphine-induced flashbacks. Still not a story. Then the game shows you sleeping in a hospital and two french men discussing killing you or something, repeatedly, for several chapters. Still not a story. I'm really confused who am I supposed to be? who gives me orders? what's my goal? None of that is clarified.If Velvet Assassin had a real story, richer consistent gameplay mechanics, and a coherent progression, it might have become a great game.

												Velvet Assassin is a much better game in theory than in practice. It has a great premise: a likable female spy who brutally assassinates Nazis to secretly turn the tide of WWII. To be clear, Velvet is a stealth game clearly designed for sneaking, and yet the stealth gameplay can be exceptionally frustrating.The sneaking system is woefully underdeveloped. There are no visibility indicators or radars or cones of vision. Trial and error is all you have. Then there’s the painfully slow sneaking speed. If you remain undetected, you get rewarded with truly great kill animations. If an enemy spots you, you have to run away or rely on wonky combat and AI exploits.The game is very linear, with a sort of paint by numbers approach to stealth, resulting in you either going about things the developers’ way or repeatedly dying. The checkpoint system can also be irksome, with some checkpoints quite far apart, making you fearful to fail simply because you don’t want to replay things again.On the bright side, the story and briefing cutscenes are done very well, building up believability and intrigue. Very strong voice acting by all characters is also a great boon, with humorous enemy dialogue akin to No One Lives Forever being a highlight. Certain mechanics like shadows, whistling, and stat upgrades do help keep things interesting. Graphically the game is bleak, brown, and barren but occasionally looks quite nice.Overall, Velvet Assassin only takes about 6 hours to finish on Normal, which is good because by the end I was very ready for it to be over. Despite the frustration there’s something charming about its very old school approach, almost daring you to try to survive. The game clearly isn’t great, but it does have some good elements. Most will wish to skip the game, but for those hardcore gamers who find the concept intriguing, Velvet Assassin is worth playing if you pick it up for real cheap.

												The mixed reception of this game is deserved especially since, at this late date, people are expecting a lot more in terms of freedom of movement and fluidity when it comes to controls. The game is technically a "stealth" game but it reminds me a lot more of the survival horror genre (particularly Silent Hill 3 in terms of controls, mood, its lighting/color scheme and female protagonist--the lady protagonist even shares Heather's psychically controlled pocket flashlight). Calculating open combat engagements is a must unless you plan on reloading quite a bit. The game rewards exploration with collectables, health, ammo, and morphine (Violette's "kill bad guys instantly" juice) hence its strong affinity with the survival horror genre. This is a game about patience, perseverance, and doing it the right way--the way the designers intended--the first time, so it might not jive with the average gamer. As far as the story goes, the lady protagonist is arguably not as fascinating as the real life French-English lady spy she is based on but she is more interesting and "strong" than the average female video game character--albeit she suffers the usual treatment of female characters in video games (she is often seen running about in her nightie) and moonlights as a helpless morphine addict incapacitated in a hospital. Ah well, at least she is complex. I just wish she was savvier in a fight and didn't die instantaneously. But In all honesty, I'm glad she is not a martial arts expert or gun toting "bro-girl," I'm also relieved she isn't a victim (though she is certainly vulnerable). She lends some much needed class to female protagonists and her touted desirability is admirably "kosher" in the sense that she is an independent and "full-bodied" woman--although the German uniform thing, I think, is a little iffy (I think of Charlotte Rampling in the Night Porter). I hope she comes back for a sequel. However, I also kind of feel that this historical fiction based on actual historical figures is better handled by Ubisoft. May Violette one day receive a big budget treatment so she can join the likes of Sam Fisher, Solid Snake, the guy from Thief and all the Brotherhood Assassins as a worthy protagonist.

												Velvet Assassin is an excellent game, let me tell you why.PROS:You're an agent behind enemy lines and you have to take out important people or sabotage bases. The gameplay is great, the stealth system fairly simple; hide in shadows, don't walk in front of people, but it can get pretty intense, especially the later levels where there are less shadows to hide in and you need to perform more daring assassinations on patroling enemies.The weapons you get are true to the era (no crossbows or whatever), fitting for an assassin: a knife and a pistol. You can't carry around clunky weapons on your back like you're some sort of Wolfenstien. However there are portions of the game where, after blowing something up, you need a less tacticle approach to escape and the shotgun is your friend. It makes sense, it doesn't seem realistic that you can be a ghost 100% of the time. Besides, if you don't go out with a bang, how are the Nazi's gonna know you were there? :)Content, I've played the game for about 8 hours and I'm not even halfway done. There's also rewards you get for exploring, albiet within the confines of the level. Not every game has to be open world/sandbox. Also, it seems there's a new way to kill enemies almost every level. The levels are also pretty unique from each other, and a lot of effort was put into level design. It doesn't get dull.Great voice acting. Excellent grahpics. Nice execution animations.CONS:You can't pick up enemy weapons, which may be helpful if you get discovered. But I guess an assassin doesn't want to be loud even if she's getting shot at.The story is a little disjointed. There isn't too much of a connection between missions, but it doesn't hurt to use your imagination a little bit and pretend that the British sent you on a new mission somewhere else, leaving the old mission behind you, cause after all it's finished.Very rarely the character movements and controls seem unnatural, like when you're trying to sneak around a corner and you have your face pressed right up to it. It's not enough to detract from the fun though. And I feel it's due to the Nvidia physix engine (AMD users can still play the game though!).Checkpoints happen about four or five times during a mission. If you're trying to play a perfect game, be prepared to reload. But, it's challenging! Not a "kill an enemy, save" type of game.Leveling up is done through finding hidden collectibles, and if you don't find them you can get underleveled. It doesn't make the game impossible, just harder than it already is. Overall, this is an excellent game even for full price which is still pretty cheap. A great way to spend a few bucks and get a lot out of it. 8.9/10Also, she has a nice butt.

												The most important thing to remember when judging Velvet Assassin is that it was a middle-market release. It admittedly does have some weaknesses, but most of these are things that are pretty well guaranteed to crop up in middle-market games, and it would be absurd to judge it by the same high standards as its big-budget AAA competitors. Once you allow yourself to get over these few niggling little problems, Velvet Assassin emerges as a superb and memorable stealth game, which definitely made the most out of its measly budget. In short, it's not the perfect stealth game (see Thief II: The Metal Age), so I wouldn't recommend it to absolute beginners as their introduction to the genre. Conversely, if you're a stealth purist you might be frustrated by this game, because while the narrative and atmosphere have both been crafted with painterly precision, the game's few faults do tend to be concentrated in the actual stealth gameplay itself. But in general, if you're a fan of stealth and dark atmospheric games then this is definitely recommended. Well worth the price!Pros:+The dark and dreamlike ambience of this game was perfectly executed, and its atmosphere is deeply immersive and unsettling.+Borrows mechanics from some of the best stealth games ever made (particularly the Thief and Hitman series) whilst also innovating with several brilliant new approaches to stealth gameplay all its own.+This could easily have been "just another game with vaguely symbolic, dark subject matter". But it's a testament to how expertly this game was written and designed that it still manages to be profoundly upsetting and truly horrific at times, even to someone who's played many games that touch on similar themes before. This is particularly impressive given that everyone already knows bad things happened in WWII, so they can't simply fake it by surprising the player with unexpected dark twists. +By 2009 standards this game really punched above its weight in the graphics department, especially its beautiful lighting effects, which hold up even today.Cons:-This game features a checkpoint-based save system, which is unbelievably frustrating in a stealth game, and therefore indirectly shatters immersion. -The light-and-shadow-based stealth system is completely binary, and occasionaly glitches in a way that renders certain rooms essentially impossible to traverse stealthily. However, it would be unreasonable to expect a middle-market title to be completely free of little problems like this.-Much of the narrative and atmosphere is communicated through overheard conversations between Nazi soldiers. Unfortunately for non-German-speakers, it's very easy to miss parts of the English subtitles for these conversations whilst you're still in the middle of gameplay at the same time. Consequently I felt like I was missing much of the rich worldbuilding and narrative these conversations conveyed.-This is not a pure stealth game, and at fairly regular intervals it forces you to gun down waves of enemies. This schizophrenic design choice means there are some sections of the game which can't be completed stealthily, and other sections which can't be completed violently, and you're often not sure which of the two you're in at any given time. This often leads to punishingly difficult scenarios, where you have to ask yourself "Am I failing because I'm just bad at the game, or am I trying to be too stealthy in a scenario where the designers have arbitrarily decided I have to be violent?" or vice versa. Unfortunately the worst instance of this problem takes place in the final few minutes of the game, where the only way you can finish the game is to gun down wave after wave of absolutely merciless enemies. I found this frustrating, punishing, and just simply not fun in any way, and it honestly ruined the ending of the game for me.-The level design, a feature of crucial importance to stealth games, is sadly quite linear most of the time, and the levels themselves are not particularly large. It wouldn't be realistic to expect significantly more from a middle-market title, but it's still a weakness. -The enemy AI is somewhat robotic and "gamey", and is especially unrealistic when you're using the social stealth mechanics. Again, little problems like this are understandable in a middle-market game.-The gameplay is quite regularly interrupted by cutscenes, although most of them are mercifully short. -There are no non-lethal combat options whatsoever.

Velvet Assassin is an 8 terrycloth towels out of 10 satin negligeesDue to Steam's character limits, the full review can be found at Gao Li Occasionally Reviews[gaolioccasionallyreviews.wordpress.com].Velvet Assassin is a breathtaking World War II stealth game about the missions of Violette Summer, a British spy loosely based on the real-life British intelligence agent Violette Szabo. Summer lies badly wounded in a hospital in France and recalls her operations behind enemy lines from the streets of occupied Paris, over Hamburg, to the Warsaw Ghetto, taking out Nazi officers and sabotaging Germany’s war machine all the while handling more than limited resources to pursue her objective. At no point does Velvet Assassin shy away from pointing out the horrors of war and tries its best to stay true to historical accuracy, but even more amazing than its premise and the suspense created within the game is that this World War II-era title was developed by a relatively small, independent German studio.


Cold blooded murder 
A Screenshot of Velvet Assassin
By: Gao Li




The GameplayGiven that this title was created by such a small company that had to shut its doors mid-2009, the game does not have as high a production value as Konami’s Metal Gear series or Square-Enix’s Hitman franchise. Because of that, the enemy AI might not be as sophisticated as in other games of the genre, nor are the levels as big as one might know them from AAA titles. Despite these restrictions, Velvet Assassin manages to very easily capture the player’s attention right from the get-go and keep it up until the very end of its roughly 16 to 20 hour long campaign. Fans of Tenchu will feel right at home here.At any given point in time, Violette can only carry up to three weapons, one of which is always her trusty knife with which she stabs Nazis from behind or slits their throats. Bullets for the guns are extremely scarce (usually she will only have about seven of them with her) and prevent players from just running and gunning through the streets of Europe. With that said, if you are an inexperienced player or become antsy quickly, Velvet Assassin is a definite pass, but if you are patient and mindful of enemy patterns, you'll have a blast of a time.In addition to the difficulty level, this game autosaves at certain spots that aren’t far away from one another area-wise, but due to the need to sneak through the levels strategically while exing off enemy soldiers, can take quite some time to get to. One of the more infuriating parts of the game is dying at a section then lurking in the shadows, waiting for the guards’ conversation to be over for the n-teenth time so they start patrolling and Violette can finally kill them and move on. At least, it was infuriating until I remembered that she can whistle to attract their attention, which not only immediately cut their conversation short, but also got them in a spot where eliminating them was that much easier.The game’s cohesiveness in enemy encounters is what I appreciated the most as there are no almost no infuriating action sequences that do not fit the gameplay style. The only problematic segment was a cover-based shooting segment against the 36th Waffen Grenadier Division of the SS also known as the Dirlewanger Brigade where players will have to fend of an onslaught of SS soldiers. Unless you are either really good at shooter games or have leveled up Violette's life meter, you will get stuck there for quite some time.


Violette disguising as a member of the SS-Helferinnenkorps 
A Screenshot of Velvet Assassin
By: Gao Li




The MorphineThe game starts off with Violette lying in a hospital in France in 1944 during the war. She is badly wounded from her latest mission and dreams about/remembers her assignments in Germany, Poland, and France. To alleviate her pain, the staff injects her with morphine that slows down the time within her dream. If killing a Nazi soldier should become too difficult for the player, the morphine can be activated as basically a freebie (By leveling up her stats, Violette will eventually be able to carry three syringes instead of one and can thus use the morphine up to three times per stage). During this morphined state, Violette runs around in a negligee for some reason, mist rises from the ground, and rose petals fall from the sky. She can then straight up run to one enemy and stab him to death. Players should be careful that whichever Nazi soldier they want to stab isn't accompanied by anyone else, as after he is killed, the game returns to normal, the other enemy soldier will be alerted, and will surely attempt to kill Violette in an instant.Design and voice actingThe design is fabulous. The stages have everything from romantic promenades to eery sewers. The music then completes the scary atmosphere and the German soldiers speak German fluently, which came as a welcome surprise.Motion BlurRegrettably, the game’s options menu is rather bareboned and might leave players with a couple of wishes. Although I do not mind, some players may not appreciate motion blur in their video games. In their cases, they can head to the 《Velvet Assassin》 folder in Windows, then go to the 《FX》 folder and then to 《PostFX》, where they can then erase the 《directional_blur.pfx》 file.


Even though these assassination screens are cool to look at, they do leave me uneasy. 
A Screenshot of Velvet Assassin
By: Gao Li




ConclusionVelvet Assassin is a must get for stealth game fans. It is very engaging and brings with it a nice twist to both the stealth as well as the World War II game genre while maintaining to be historically accurate with just enough artistic license to make the game as thrilling as it is. The music, the graphic design, and the voiceover are superb, but the fight against the Dirlewanger Brigade can put a dent into things. Being a small studio’s game, the less sophisticated enemy AI is definitely forgivable and so is the fact that stages are not the same size as in Metal Gear. The options menu is not perfect, but everything that can be customized, is easily accessible in the game’s folders (provided one knows where to look and what to look for). With all that in mind, Velvet Assassin is an outright gritty game that does not shy away from discussing the horrors of the Nazi regime. Stealth game fans will most certainly enjoy it and feel right at home.

												What do you do in this game?  It's a nice, simple stealth game that takes place during WWII.  Like many stealth games, you creep around in the shadows, staying out of the light, you can sneak up on enemies to silently kill them, and you can hide their bodies to keep the other enemies from finding them.  Other stealthy things include wearing a disguise, whistling to get  your enemies' attention, breaking fuse boxes to knock out lights, shooting flamable/explosive stuff to kill your enemies, wearing a gas mask and releasing poison gas to kill a lot of enemies at once, pulling the pin on their grenades to turn them into walking time bombs, and a few other exciting ways to kill, confuse, and evade your enemies that I'm probably not thinking about. In terms of gunplay, most of this game involves stealth, so you won't be doing as much shooting as you would in other games.  You do get a silenced pistol on most missions, but very little ammo.  Other weapons include a flare gun, a Lugar pistol, a shotgun, sniper rifle, and an STG-44.  The noisier weapons tend to be rare, and only available at certain points in the game.  The lugar is semi- common though.Overall, I did enjoy this game and much of what it had to offer, but as usual, every game has its cons.  As many have stated, checkpoints tend to be spaced a little far apart at times.  This means that if you get killed, you will have to redo quite a bit of gameplay.  It's not quite as bad as some of the other reviews have stated, but it can be frustrating. I'm not the most patient person when it comes to games, but I can honestly say that I never wanted to "rage quit" at any point of this game.  Sure, the checkpoint thing is frustrating, but the good gameplay more than makes up for it.  In other words, I really loved this game.8.5/10

												I so desperately wanted to like this game, even more than that, I wanted to *love* it! The setting and story is fascinating, based on the real life French-English spy Violette Szabo, during WWII. She's a great character and her model is gorgeous, the soundscapes are great, the enemies actually speak German (it used to be rather uncommon a few years back that any character spoke their native tounge, unless it happened to be English), and the light effects are nice.But the fact is, the game is punishingly difficult. Relying mostly on stealth tactics, the fist few episodes works fine to ease you into the games mechanics. You can even feel it is a bit too unbelievable that guards patrolling would spot you only to forget you were crawling into a vent or something a moment later, even for game logic. But then there's a difficulty spike that will have you ragequit the game after a number of failed attempts. It's not that you don't know what to do, it's how hard it is to actually do it in this game. 												Overall 7/10Velvet Assassin is a pretty basic “old-school” stealth game, however, the mechanics are solid and the unique setting and well thought out presentation turn it into an overall good game for people that like the genre. If you didn’t like the likes of Thief or the older Splinter Cell titles or need massive freedom in approaching your strategy like in Dishonored, Velvet Assassin will certainly not change your mind.The title is very linear and the majority of time you spend crouching in shadowy corners, figuring out enemy patrol patterns and move slowly in for the kill, hoping you didn’t miss any observant Nazi in viewing or hearing distance. The enemy AI is not that good, they follow their patterns and investigate suspicious activities. Your hero Violette is not Solid Snake and there not many gadgets or weapons to be used, mainly it’s you, your knife and the shadows. The difficulty level is high and most of the time there is only one right way to get through a scenario. This means a lot of Trial & Error (and repetition due to a checkpoint system), but it makes success rewarding and the controls are precise enough to almost never make it frustrating. The almost comes from some forced action sequences that can get overwhelming too easily especially toward the end of the game.Velvet Assassin takes itself serious, there is no humor to be found, the world is dark and depressing, but at the same time beautifully presented. This is very fitting for the World War 2 setting that is relatively fresh for this kind of game. The narrative structure interesting, full of dark themes and delivered by solid voice actors, overall I would call the game emotionally engaging and that is one of the things that definitely make it worth playing, even though the gameplay doesn’t offer that much variety. The campaign is relatively short and things wrap up before they can get boring. I recommend Velvet Assassin to all stealth fans or gamers that are interested in a darker more personal World War 2 setting, definitely worth playing and the short campaign won’t take that much time to finish.Pros:- emotionally engaging- solid stealth mechanics- good story in a beautiful settingCons:- linear (not much freedom) and short- frustrating forced shoot-outs

												It is a 3rd Person, stealth game with "Sabotage" and "Kill" missions. If you like Splinter Cell and Hitman series, this game may be right for you. But beware: it has its many flaws, but is playable as soon you fix the start crash message asking for Physx drivers. I set Ant-aliasing to "maximum" and the game now works under Win10. My comments are based on 60% of the game so far (7 missions in 11 hours), playing with a XBOX controller for Windows.Overall - 8 out 10Story 10 out 10 - It is a german game based on the 2nd real mission of a French agent, Lieutenant Violette Szabó. This game follows the "Kill some nazis, sabotage and flee" approach. Story is narrated by main character briefing the mission and presenting further objectives while reaching critical checkpoints by showing some (skipable) short cutscenes. After carefull consideration, I decided to give a 10 for being inspired in real events AND I am really planning to read her biography written by her daugther, Tania Szabó: https://www.amazon.com/Young-Brave-Beautiful-Operations-Lieutenant-ebook/dp/B00TNTA8QA/ref=pd_sim_351_4?ie=UTF8&psc=1&refRID=KBPWMBHCASHYPRA0YHQXLevel design  & Graphics - 8 out 10 - For a 2009 title, they could be better, but is detailed enough to portrait the WW2 setting. Nothing special so far. At least, few maps have a few different routes to complete a mission. Best part is after reaching a checkpoint, you can go back to collect items, ammo, medkits, etc. So, game is not purely linear.Game lenght - 6 out 10 - Missions are short and based on "infiltrate, find a key, open a locked door, find a plot item, and continue further to mission's objective. Then, get the hell out there". You can beat a mission in 45 to 90 min. The best part is that you need to be careful and think about the right tactical approach to each mission. Sometimes, you can evade all enemies, sometimes, killing is mandatory. Ammo is rare, so think twice.Game Features - 10 out 10 - It combines splinter cell and hitman series as I have said before, AND the possibility to "level up" your character in three categories: Stealth, Morphine and Strength. For instance, you can upgrade the morphine's effect duration if you see fit.   1. You gain XP for each completed mission and collectible you may find due to exploration on the map. That means, you need to kill some nazis in most of the maps for safer exploration. However, I have noticed that some kills are not really necessary, but it will take longer to finish that map.    2. Inventory - as a standard feature, nothing special. Weapons, medkit, flashlight, and morphine (used to speed up the time for you, so a targeted enemy will not have enough reflexes to kill you, even if you go running towards him in a frontal attack. You can kill just one enemy at a time, by pressing attack buttom once you get close enough to him).    3. Mission map - very short zoomable maps, 45-90 min length each, with 3-4 checkpoints. Here is one of the most hated feature of the game I read on the players' reviews. The game forces you to think carefully before attemping a movement or an attack. Simple put: do not rush and you going to make it. Additionally, there are 'secret objectives' based on personal interests of the main character. You really need to explore the map to figure out.   4. Collectibles - just to justify your XP points. It could be used for additional XP instead. Additional XP points should be earned by completing a map with no kill, for instance, or for not triggering an alarm. For short, it could be better designed.   5. Controller support and controller customization - Additionally to Mouse and Keyboard, the game can recognizes a gamepad, AND you can change buttom layout as you see fit. IMHO, an interesting feature. I have never seen gamepad customization in any other PC game.    6. Mission briefing. The main character narrates every mission briefing with a combination of pictures and short movies to introduce you you next mission.    7. Stealth - As you enter in a shadowed zone, your silluete turns into purple, and you character becomes invisible to enemies,  similar to splinter cell series. You can turn lights off to avoid being detected. You can drag bodies to hide them.   8. Interaction. Loot corpses, open closets and lockers, insert a bomb, use an uniform as disguise (requires a closet or cabinet to change clothes), use items, use armor vest, change clothes, pick up plot items up, climb fences, change weapons, reload, pick collectibles up, open doors, peek through keyholes, crouch, run/walk, aim guns, crawl into a wall hole, turn radios on/off and whistle to lure enemies, electrify a flooded area to shock enemies, pick up, drag-to-hide bodies, push crates, jump over a gap, climb over a crate, climb a ladder, climb down, jump down a floor hole, use a flahslight, use morphine, disarm electrified fences, shoot explosive/gas barrels, use gas masks, light enemies on fire with a flare gun, perform silent lethal takedowns (my favorite part), listen to footsteps to guess enemy distance and walking path behind doors. Note: When using a german uniform, your footsteps becomes louder due to the high heels. AND as you get too close to an enemy, he will figure out and you disguise will be blown up. So, change clothes wisely whenever possible. Once disguised, there will be a 'proximity bar' indicator to warn you about. The closer (to an enemy), the smaller (the bar).    9. Weapons. Standard: Combat Knife and pistol (silenced Colt) AND rare to find: flare guns to incinerate enemy, loud german pistols, sniper rifle, and shotguns. The bad is you cannot accumulate guns. Every mission starting point you go back to basic weapons (knife and silent Colt pistol). AND ammo is scarse. Meaning, it is not a shooter game. Period.   10. Mission stats - every completed missions presents a summary of number of enemies killed out of maximum possible, collectibles found, XP earned, etc. Nothing special.Enemy AI - 6 out 10 - The controversial part of the game. AI is dumb, but extremelly lethal and accurate. That means do not try anything rushed or stupid (like crouching or aiming a gun while disguised), otherwise you gonna be killed. If you want to give it a try, at least buy it on sale.

												This is a pretty neat game despite how rough the experience can get at times. You play as Violet, a secret agent who really likes stabbing nazis. The story isn't one of the game's strong suits and it doesn't need to be, because the stealth gameplay is quite good and is complemented by pretty well designed levels. The challenge is really good as the AI can be quite nasty at times and any mistake will punish you. There's a variety of ways you can take out nazi scum and they're all equally satisfying, be it electricuting them, stabbing them in the balls, or pulling one's grenade pin and turning him into a walking time bomb unbeknownst to him and his buddies he's chatting with. There's even a little bit of Hitman-style stealth where you can sometimes put on an SS uniform as a disguise (which Violet looks quite cute in). For a game released in 2009 it looks quite nice, and comparable to titles released even six years later.The game isn't without its flaws though, and they're pretty ugly ones, the worst being the save system being checkpoint-based. To me, checkpoints have no place in stealth games, and this one stinks on ice. Stealth is a genre where you're constantly in delicate situations, and one little mistake will just mess everything up. Having checkpoints be minutes apart is just abusive, and it's not helped by the ludicrous AI. I like a good challenge in my stealth, but it was often that the AI felt just downright ♥♥♥♥ing clairvoyant. If you spook a nazi, no matter how or where he'll just converge on your position. You can make a noise and sneak to the other side of the damn area and he'll keep following you, almost as if he just knows you're there. Another thing I think has no place in stealth games is forced action/shooting segments, and there's more than a handful present. The game really falls apart in the last stage because of this, as it's almost nothing but forced gunfights. There's also the occasional bug here and there but what modern game doesn't have those.This game has been undeservedly neglected since its release six years ago. Despite its nasty flaws, there's a lot to like here, and it feels good to play a game that'll push my♥♥♥♥♥♥in for any mistake I make, especially in an age where stealth has fallen from grace and has been relegated to garbage pseudo-stealth you see in big-name games nowadays. Not to mention it's so damn cheap you'd be wrong not to give it a shot. Hell, if it's too hard for you, you can even mess with config files and make it easy for your casual baby butt to handle.

												Vicariously view violent Violette vehemently victimize valueless Nazis. I’m not sure why I went with the unneeded alliteration but I’m not sure why the developers went with velvet. Maybe they were trying to turn Violet into velvet for some reason but…whatever…Velvet Assassin takes places in the early/mid 1940s. You’re a British assassin named Violette Summer who’s based off, in first name, hairstyle, and background only, of real world British assassin Violette Szabo[en.wikipedia.org]. Violette single handedly either takes out several high ranking Nazi leaders (who didn’t exist) or helped lead to the destruction of several Nazi outposts including the real-life mission Operation Gomorrah[en.wikipedia.org]. She does this with her well placed knife and a Nazi jugular vein. She also uses a silenced pistol but …ugh. More on this unfortunate mechanic later. Stealth is both very good and very bad at the same time. Apparently, Nazi’s were very blind individuals. A light shade in otherwise broad daylight can keep them from noticing you. It seems odd that any darkness can be that good in a, mostly, realistic stealth game. The game does have a higher difficulty so if you want to skip the, “Does Violette have special shadow moving powers?” go ahead play that. I hear it’s painfully real. The game also has ‘Morphine Mode’, which allows you to travel unnoticed or get a face to face kill cam. It might seem like a supernatural power but you learn the first 10 missions are all flashbacks so morphine mode is a foggy memory of how Violette got that kill. The final two are “current time” missions. As you go through missions you find collectables and hidden achievements (found through exploration) which, when you reach 1000 exp, allows you to upgrade a stat, either morphine mode; which increases syringe count and length, stealth; which allows you move faster, or strength; which makes you tankier. The collectables are various war medals and paraphernalia, some of which have interesting back stores but I feel like there could have been expanded to allow for more backstory. You might start feeling sympathy for Nazis through. There’s a few instances where the horrors of war appear all too human and you feel a little guilty as poor Gretchen won’t be seeing her husband because of you. They may be literal Nazi’s but they still dream and love like the good ol’ boys in [insert country flag colors here]. That’s one of the things the game does really well. The carnage of WWII is evident in every aspect of the game. Dead bodies litter the streets of Warsaw, Poland. Several children are apart of the body count as they hang in various trees in France. Some enemies are even given a soul when they wish none of this has happened and just want to go back home; not everyone follows the leader in war. There’s even one letter where the writer says he’s ready to die due to the nightmare reality. VA has 12 missions which average out an hour of play time (not sure if time resets on death). Checkpoints are all over the place but getting to them can be very painful. The slowness of the game is apparent when you have to kill a large amount of enemies in a less than straight forward way where you get caught, die and have to try again. Missions like level 6 might be a game killer if you’re not dedicated. The first 10 levels are wonderful, albeit a crawl at times. “Realistic” stealth mechanics where hiding in the shadows, behind a crate, or disguised as the only female SS officer in the game are the way to victory as there’s not enough ammo to go Rambo. That all changes in the last two levels and therein is where the game devolves into pain. You see, Velvet Assassin stops being about stealth and turns into a third person shooter. This would be fine but the shooting aspects are very poor. The crosshair is there but bullets don’t always go where you’d think, enemies can be randomly resistant to damage, and general aim abilities are just awful. You know how many games have ice levels and you don’t stop when you want to stop? That’s what aiming in this game feels like. If you move a little, it doesn’t move but if you move a lot you just turned 360 degrees while barely trying. This can be mitigated by using a mouse but even then it needs a lot of work. To exacerbate the terrible aiming, the stealth mechanic goes away. Enemies are suddenly more likely to see you, even in deep shadows and getting enemies alone where you can get a knife skill is nearly impossible and it comes from nowhere. You can get through all but one or two levels in the first 10 without shooting anyone but suddenly it’s the only way to progress. Along with the sudden genre shift, the developers tried to add some sex to the game. Violette stops wearing jackets and black ‘armor’ and now dons only a white negligée (and the velvet in Velvet Assassin) due to story reasons. She’s also very shiny for, uh, ‘plot’. It turns a hardnosed female assassin into a male fetish. There’s no option to get dressed and even in the credit epilogue she’s in her underwear. It’s like the last two levels were done by a different team. The game could have been great but due to the ending levels, it turns itself into mediocre at best. As for non-gameplay aspects: Voice acting it nice. Our Heroine sounds smooth and pleasant and at no point do you ever wish for her to shut-up. Maybe it’s the English accent (from a New York born, German for five years raised woman) or the lower tones but I’d like to hear Melinda Y. Cohen[en.wikipedia.org] more often. The German enemies spoke German (with subtitles if you don’t speak the language) so there’s some immersion for ya.Music is…eh. You hear the sound of gunfire too often and in places where you shouldn’t be hearing gunfire. It can also throw you off and make you think someone saw you. Otherwise, it’s all atmospheric. It ramps up when you’ve been spotted and it always makes me feel like I screwed-up when I hear it. Not sure if that was the purpose but that’s the outcome so, to be honest, I’m digging it. There are no official sources so here’s some Youtube videos. There’s actually more tracks than I thought and there’s less than one page in the link. The art helps contribute perfectly to the doom and gloom of war. There are no vibrant colors and blue skies are replaced by a dark, dirty, orange. There aren’t even any stars in the sky. Everything else is stone, iron, and ground. No hope, no freedom, no future. Welcome to war. That being said, the Paris skyline from the river Seine (or what I think is the river) circa 1943 looks beautiful even in high overcast and fog.The game has its sufferable flaws but for .49 USD cents which is what I paid for it during a summer sale (so the price of 8-16 cards), it’s well worth it. It’s a slow plough through the first 10 levels (which is what to expect from a stealth game) and the third person shooting genre change makes the game way less fun so at full price, don’t buy it; it’s not worth it. I really wish I could recommend at full price but my frustrations at needing to relearn the game 5/6ths of the way in makes It hard. File it under cult classic. Troubleshooting:For whatever reason, modern technology hates Velvet Assassin so, in order to play the game, you may need to download the Nvidia legacy driver located here[www.nvidia.com]. It’s free, fast, and easy.

												Have you ever thought of yourself as a cold blooded killer focused on your mission to eradicate the Nazi scourge infecting 1940’s France? Then this is the game for youThis game is a great third person action/stealth game with a fairly good combat system. The game is full of tense moments and tight confined spaces. It’s pretty standard for a world war two spy setting, your job is to defeat bag guys and gain intel. It does take place in retrospective, you see what’s going to happen but it’s the getting there that’s interesting. The characters themselves though are rather two dimensional to be honest, it’s hard to pin down why but I didn’t feel particularly connected to Violette, even when the story develops. Pick this game up and enjoy the ride, especially if it’s on sale. The game has not aged amazingly and there were several glitches, none of which game breaking. 												I tried this game thinking it would be interesting.  I liked the two sniper games I played recently, and although this is a different type of game, I thought it would be good, too.  I understand that stealth-based games tend to be difficult, but I think this one is excessively hard.  Even on the easier difficulty level, after ~30 minutes of playing and making multiple attempts, I was still unable to pass the first pair of guards.  Killing the first was easy, but I couldn't get past the second after that.  I expect the beginning of a game like this basically to be instructions on how the game works and what you'll need to do throughout the game.  The start should be relatively easy.  Here, it's not.  There's little instruction besides wait for the two guards to separate (which is semi-obvious), and you're pretty much on your own to figure out how to pass the second guard after taking out the first, something I wasn't able to do.  Had this happened later in the game, I'd accept it as a tricky part of a stage, but having this happen right in the beginning of the game is extremely frustrating.  Maybe I'll come back to this some day, but for now I've uninstalled it.  It's hard to get into a game when I can't even pass the beginning section without massive difficulty.  More dedicated players or people who like stealth games might enjoy this.  But given what I see as excessive difficulty right in the beginning of the game, I can't really recommend this.Update:  Thanks to a comment on this review, I finally passed the intro mission and got to the next one.  However, I still don't really like that the intro wasn't a self-walkthrough, and I'm still finding the game overall to be slow-moving and rather difficult, even very early on.  That's probably the point here, but I'm not really enjoying it.  Every time I die at a harder part, I have to redo the easier parts before it, and this happens over and over again, making things feel repetitive.  Also, in some sniper games I played recently, I felt like I had a fighting chance if I got spotted, but here I feel like I'm just dead meat.  Maybe this isn't my type of game.  Perhaps in small doses, it will be OK, but I think I'll just end up frustrated if I try to play this for a long time at once.  As I said originally, if you like this type of game in general, you'll probably like this specific game, but I don't think it's for me, and for more casual gamers like me, I wouldn't recommend it because of the rather high difficulty level it seems to have.

												Not exactly my usual preference of game but being of the WW2 variety I decided to take a chance as the last time I did so (Return to Castle Wolfenstein) my choice was proven a correct one.  Set in WW2 you assume the role of Violette Summer, which was inspired by a real life heroine by the name of Violette Szabo, which is an pretty incredible life story itself for anyone with a passion for history.  The mood of this game is what one would truly expect of war-torn Europe; bleak, fearful, violent and sad.  The opening movie pretty much sums the game up in my opinion, not to spoil it for anyone but it reminds me of that eerie opening to one of my favourite TV series; The World at War were humanity is destroying itself in an unforgiving darkened world.  Now your role as Violette is to infiltrate and end the lives of the darkest and most corrupt seeds in the Third Reich (well you blow stuff up too) in quick and quiet fashion then escape - no charging about like Master Chief, you're an assassin not god with a gun and a green suit because believe me this game can be unforgiving when caught.  Now I very much recommend a Xbox controller or something similar when play this game as the controls are very clunky even on controller, especially when shooting.  The visuals and sound are very satisfying and in-sync with the mood; sombre and eerie would be my quick description.  There is one mechanic that does stand out however and that is the morphine power, to put it simply when injected you enter a slow down mode where you can damn near do anything which does kill the immersion somewhat.  The A.I aren't too bright in the game either, then not many games pull that off but they are not without character.  They have seen war and it has touched them deeply and some of the conversations you hear are truly horrific.       Now this game is certainly not for everyone, but to anyone like me who plays stealthy characters in any game with the option to do so will feel right at home with this game.  You choose the right weapons for your mission, disguise yourself when necessary and gather intelligence when and if you can.              I would give this game a 4/5 for it truly is an enjoyable game with a few flaws.

												A somewhat mediocre, but very good third-person shooter released 5 years ago (2009). You are Violette, a British female spy who attempts to weaken Nazi Germany in World War II. The game employs a stealth-based gameplay-style characterised by the following things:--shadows are your best friend and you can hide without soldiers being able to see you--this is a must - once you are seen it is difficult to survive the firefight--you have morphine syringes at your disposal: once you use these the game becomes slow-mo and you can easily eliminate the guards who have noticed you; you need to look for these syringes as you can quickly run out of "ammo"--wearing a disguise: Violette can pick up an SS uniform which means you can move freely amongst the German soldiers; you cannot get too close to them and you need to be careful as to what action you performViolette receives experience points which allow you to upgrade her skills. This is just a minor RPG element and to be honest nothing unusual or exciting. Also, the more collectibles you find the more XP you can collect - it's worth looking around wherever you go on each level.The game is OK for its price, especially if discounted (the last time it cost 0.99 EUR). Stealth mechanics are not the best and what I never understood is that if a game wants you to go stealth why does it employ a level which is based on combat? The last level is all about combat and it is very tedious. Putting this one aside the story of Violette seems interesting and the game's art design is quite good along with the music and the German voice acting.If you do not have any particular game in mind and are looking for a good discounted software Velvet Assassin should be your pick.

												A very simple and fun stealth game.Enemy AI is basic, unaware of their missing comrades, and blind to the hazards of their surroundings. Mind you, if you're spotted, they are above-average shots and will swarm upon you. In these scenarios, you can either shoot back -- with gun-play that doesn't operate well, outside of sneaking head-shots -- or hide -- enemies stay in their zones, you can identify zones by the doors that you can enter but have no opening animation --.There are three skills to level up, to help you along as you play. You gain experience by completing secret side-missions and by picking up collectibles. While you will not gain experience for most of your kills, sometimes a collectible can be found when searching the bodies of your fallen enemies. The one unique feature of this stealth game is the "Morphine" item. Upon use, time will stop momentarily, giving you the opportunity to run away/past a tricky situation, or silently kill an enemy head-on. It can be a saving grace when backed into a corner, but you also might forget that the item is even there.Game-play becomes very repetitive, quickly. To keep the game fresh, I can not play more than 1 or 2 missions in a session. Which is a shame, but with a bargain asking price of $5 or less, it's hard to regret this purchase.Over-all, I'd give it a grade of C+.

												Maybe I made a mistake by going into this game thinking it would be decent, because mostly all it did was disappoint. I couldn't even start the game because of an error message, so right off the bat I was getting a great impression. After searching the forums and finding the solution on some old threads, I had to download some missing files for PhysX, of which you'd think they could have bundled with the game's download, but whatever.After all that I finally got the the main menu... which you cannot navigate with your mouse. Must be a console port. Oh, but my gamepad doesn't work either. So it's a poorly made console port, fantastic. I configure settings and start up the campaign, greeted with one of the most boring intro videos I've seen in a long while. Once I'm in the game, it runs pretty terrible, so I have to quit entirely to change the video settings that can only be set from the launcher's splash screen before you actually launch the game itself, because why would we want to configure video settings from the in-game options, right? My specifications far exceed the Recommended System Requirements, good components made after the game's release, but I still have to turn things down, so evidently optimization wasn't a priority. You also cannot use the Steam overlay by default, and the "fix" for this is to rename the executables so that Steam will launch the actual game instead of the launcher, meaning you won't be able to edit your video settings again as readily.Now for the gameplay itself. It is a stealth game, first and foremost, but it isn't a very good one. Oftentimes the game puts you in situations where it's near-impossible to sneak up behind someone before he turns around, mostly because your movement speed while sneaking is far slower than an enemy's casual walking speed. You can increase this movement speed through an arbitrary level-up screen, and while I normally don't mind RPG elements in non-RPG games if they're done right, this one feels out of place and like it only exists to handicap the player. The effect of increasing the skill is hardly noticeable too, even at the maximum value.You're supposed to be playing as a badass operative, alone and far behind enemy lines, but I'm not sure how she got that far if she's slow as a snail.You can also increase how tough your character is so you can take more damage before dying. Your character is already quite frail in terms of how quickly you can die if caught, but if the goal is not to be seen, why is there even an option of increasing your health? They certainly don't give you enough ammo to have the freedom to go in guns blazing. At least, not until the very last mission where it actually devolves into a crappy shooter. You have to rely on sneaking and stabbing. In some cases, you can simply avoid enemies, but the game rewards you with stealth kills, so there's incentive in trying to take out your enemies. Not only does the game rank your performance for each mission based on stealth kills, but you also restore a small amount of health for performing them.Of course, because the game puts you in situations where you're likely to get spotted from some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, you're probably going to take some damage every now and then, assuming you aren't killed outright, which is just as likely. It feels like the game tries to make up for this, not by correcting its mistakes, but by almost admitting it has them. There's medkits and morphine littered all over the place. You'd think those two items might serve the same purpose, but they don't. Medkits heal your damage taken while morphine is essentially your Get Out of Jail Free Card. The morphine won't save you from all situations, but if you're caught (and you will be), you can kill the enemy as if through a stealth kill. However, no matter the duration, you can still only kill one enemy during your morphine rush, so if there's more than one guy together, you're still screwed if you try to kill one. In these situations, you're better off using the morphine to reposition and hide elsewhere. Both of these items can be found frequently, as if to say, "You'll probably need these because the game isn't exactly well-designed."There are no manual saves. I can understand this from one perspective, because it's really easy to cheese a stealth game if you can save at any time. But on the other hand, reloading from the last checkpoint will sometimes feel like it's disrespecting your time. For example, there's one part where you enter an area where two guards blocking the path will immediately start talking to one another. Despite talking to each other, rather than facing one another, they both face player's direction. There's no way around them and you're forced to wait a solid minute or so for them to shut up and move on before you can even progress. Dying at any point before the next checkpoint means you'll have to sit through this conversation in its entirety, every time. Actually, these conversations you must sit through happen frequently, not as a one-time thing.Speaking of chatter, the dialog in this game is just awful. The voice actress does an okay job at best (except for this one particular letter she reads quite poorly if it's found in a shack), but the script she's reading from feels like it was written by a child. In the mission briefings, the choice of words comes across as dull, predictable, and repetitive. And throughout the levels, your character will occasionally chime in with a statement basically telling you either what you know you're to do next, or what you're already doing, which is entirely unnecessary.Also, you know how I said this is primarily a stealth game? The developers must have bipolar game design syndrome, because at the end of every operation, you're forced into firefights with enemy soldiers. I guess they must have thought that ending a mission by successfully being covert was too boring, so they had to throw in things like a rushed escape scene or a shootout to keep your interest. Nothing says congruent design like sneaking through enemy ranks only to attempt to turn your squishy stealth operative into an action movie hero at the very end, surely alerting anyone nearby who isn't dead.Although, when it comes to alerting others, the game isn't exactly convincing. When spotted, your enemies will open fire and shout, "Alarm! Alarm!" or something similar. You can even hear what sounds like maybe an alarm going off briefly. If another enemy was in that same room, or maybe the next room if a door was open, they'll come searching too. But anyone else nearby in the level will remain oblivious that there is an intruder. Part of this may be because guards are unable to enter or leave most rooms. Seriously, if you get caught, you can go through a door and the enemy cannot follow you. After a while of peeking through the keyhole, you can see them give up, exasperated with their designers for having given them such a shortcoming. Then the enemy will go back to singing that same dumb tune as if his comrade wasn't just murdered. You may find yourself retreating to previous rooms often when the game shows its incredibly unfair level design.Please see the comments section of this to read the whole review.Sorry, I hit the character limitations.

												So, in the '40s there was this little scuffle called World War II.And during this time, a woman named Violette Szabo joined the British Army.She married a French soldier, worked a number of military positions, found out she was a bit pregnant and took some time off to give birth to her child, then went right back into duty.A few months after her little girl was born, her husband was killed in action.And that just♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥her off.Seeking some Nazi-revenge, she accepted a field position, and went into Spec Ops.The only thing she ever screwed up in training was a parachute landing. Once. Pulled it off just fine after she recovered from the sprained ankle.Her only weakness was that damn ankle.She had a talent for dead-aim with a gun, sabotage, and undetected assassination.Basically she was a stone-cold Nazi-stopping machine, and one HELL of a spy.While heading to a mission, she got stopped by an unexpected road checkpoint, at which point an apparent firefight broke out. Her comrade got away, but she sprained the ankle again, and was captured after running out of bullets.She was taken prisoner, and almost escaped from the camp, before being moved. Eventually her true identity was discovered, leading to her interrogation, and tragic execution.This game is inspired by her.And I must assert INSPIRED BY, since it is not a telling of the Story of Violette Szabo, but a character based on her.A strong, intelligent, skilled woman working as an active spy, infiltrating Nazi territory and getting some hardcore Nazi-vengeance.If you like badass female protagonists, just go ahead and get this game.It should be noted that there are some questionable choices, like the highly sexualised, skimpy gown she wears in "Morphine Mode" and some pre-rendered pinup-style loading-screen images.And look, I'll forgive the pinup renders in general - it fits with the World War II theme... though it must be said that sexualising a hospitalised woman is incredibly problematic... but the Morphine Mode change felt mostly unnecessary.Get past that, though, and you're sneaking about in a solid WWII Stealth game, taking down Nazis from the shadows.You do not get the ammo to shoot your way through, so you will rely on stealth executions. You have a very small health allowance, too, adding to the "no really, stealth is the way to go" factor.This is NOT a "shoot 'em all" WWII Nazi-killing game.Go play Wolfenstein or something, if that's what you're after.One of its shortcomings is the AI. Completely incapable, apparently, of thinking "hey, maybe that spy we were just chasing is on the other side of the door we just saw her run through!"They have a very short memory, and attention-span.Certainly, the AI is the weakest part of the game, and breaks the immersion, but as the detection mechanics are pretty unforgiving, you'll probably be grateful that all it takes for them to forget about you is to hide behind a door, and watch through the keyhole as they go back to their post.One particularly interesting element was its presentation of the Nazi soldiers. Often dehumanised, faceless, evil goons, here you get to see what a spy would have encountered - casual chatter: Feeling sorry for the drunk guy (you just killed) for his apparent alcoholism after the things he'd seen during the war. General complaining about when the replacement next shift will arrive. Arguments over who stole someone's chocolate.It's an unusual thing to see Nazi soldiers humanised, and it really does add a lot to the atmosphere - they're normal human beings; when unaware of observation, they will behave as such. It's a simple thing, but it really adds to the feeling of being a spy; seeing things you wouldn't normally see, like your enemy being so normal - so casual.Perfect? No.Good? Totally.Recommended? Yes.
